comments:
This course is aimed at providing current and future product design/development engineers, manufacturing engineers, and product development managers with an applied understanding of Design for Manufacturability (DFM) concepts and methods.  The course content includes materials from multiple disciplines including engineering design, manufacturing, marketing, finance, project management, and quality systems.

Students complained that the lectures were a “verbatim reiteration of reading.” They felt that new information, such as “the application of concepts,” should have been presented. One student noted that the course was “restricted to theoretical knowledge.” A majority of students commented that all course documents were worded poorly, which caused them “unnecessary stress and confusion.” However, many felt that they learned “a great deal about design for manufacturing,” and deemed it to be worthwhile overall.

One student remarked that Professor Yim spoke too softly during lecture, while his co-teacher Professor Sarbacker was too loud. Another student noted that Professor Yim did his best to maintain interest during lectures.

Students unanimously agreed that there was too much work, and that the quality of the assignments could have been better. Readings were required for the weekly quizzes, which consisted of “obscure questions” that “did not really test for understanding.” More than a few described the grading system as “bizarre” and not accurately reflective of the effort they put into the class. The class met on Thursdays at 9pm, a time which many students thought to be quite inconvenient.
